Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Undergraduate Computer Research (UnCoRe) In Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This CISE Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site award funds a REU site at Oakland University. Each summer, undergraduate students from across the nation will work on challenging research problems related to cybersecurity, an area of national priority for our nation. Students will work with faculty mentors to use tools and techniques to solve problems that are timely and important. This site should help develop computing professionals who can build future computing systems and applications that are secure and trustworthy and that we can all use with confidence. This REU experience provides students with the foundations and inspiration to pursue computing careers and research in areas that are rapidly evolving and impacting all of our citizens.

The site will focus on recruiting women and students from institutions where there are limited research opportunities. The team will use successful strategies employed in past REU Sites to recruit undergraduate students from groups traditionally under-represented in computer science. The site includes a significant research component combined with professional development opportunities for the participating undergraduate students. The students are immersed into a research environment with all of its facets: participating actively in shaping a research project and in defining the solution; communicating to peers and other audiences about the research and their findings; visiting research laboratories and attending scientific and technical presentations; and forming collegial relationships with research teams that include faculty, graduate students, and other scientific researchers. The resulting research is often presented at professional conferences and included in technical publications thus contributing to the body of research related to sustaining secure and trustworthy cyberspace. The ultimate goal is to contribute to the development of a diverse scientific workforce with expertise in areas critical to national security in the evolving global society of the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Undergraduate Computer Research (UnCoRe) REU site has been hosted in the Computer Science and Engineering Department at Oakland University (OU) for almost two decades. The major goal of this REU Site is to each year engage 10 undergraduate students, particularly women and Under Represented Minorities (URMs), in 10-week summer research experiences that excite and motivate them to embark upon graduate studies and pursue careers in science and engineering. The intellectual focus for the REU Site is Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC). 

1. Diversity: We have a diverse group of REU participants during 2015-2017. A total of 32 undergraduate students, 9 of them female, 5 Hispanic, 5 African Americans, from 25 different universities across the U.S., have successfully taken part in the program. Although our NSF grant generally provided funding for 30 students, we sought and obtained additional funding from OU to support 2 additional students. The students came from a variety of institutions, including 4-year colleges, colleges with limited graduate programs, and institutions designated by the Carnegie Foundation as being research intensive and extensive universities, as well as community colleges. Most had no prior research or co-op/internship.

2. Publications and Awards: The REU research projects carried out by the REU students during 2015-2017 have directly resulted in 2 conference presentations, 17 poster presentations, 3 journal papers, and several awards, e.g.,

  • Seaver Thorn and Harrison Mansour won the award for the Best Poster at the 2018 IEEE International Conference in Consumer Electronics (ICCE).
  • Andrew Davis and Matthew Wagner won the award for Best Full Paper at ACM Proceedings of the 12th annual Cyber and Information Security Research Conference (CISRC2017) held at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee.

3. Scholarships: Many of the UnCoRe participants received scholarships by the graduate schools where they were admitted and by NSF. Below we only list a sample of scholarships that resulted directly from the students? research at UnCoRe during 2015-2017.

  • Harrison Mansour was awarded the Fulbright award to study in Finland for two years.
  • Matthew Wagner won the student scholarships to pursue a Ph.D. degree in Cyber Security at Missouri University of Science and Technology.
  • Richard Yang won the student scholarship to pursue a Master degree in Computer Science (Artificial Intelligence) at Stanford University.

4. Students Perceptions, Preparation, and Attitude: Students recruited to participate in UnCoRe come into the program with very little or no research literacy as illustrated by the answers they provide in the initial research quiz. As they leave the program, the students not only acquire literacy in all aspects of research through experience, but also gain a positive appreciation of computing, familiarity with some of the computing research literature, form a network of faculty and other researchers that they can use as mentors and resource for advice, and gain an understanding of how the research they conducted fits within the larger context. This statement is based on the answers the students provide on the exit surveys and our analysis of the data.

On a scale of 1 to 5, with 1 being poor and 5 being excellent, students in all three cohorts have consistently reported satisfaction with the program. For example, in 2017, students reported that they became familiar with the relevant scientific literature for their research projects (4.3 rating), developed a sense of how their research contributes to scientific knowledge (4.5 rating), developed a mentor relationship with faculty on whom they can call for guidance in the future (4.2 rating), understood the practical applications of their research (4.2 rating), understood the overall research project and how their work will contribute to its success (4.5 rating), learned more about the publishing process in engineering and science (4.3 rating), got the opportunity to learn more about other faculty and student projects in addition to their own (4.6 rating), developed skills on making scientific presentations (4.5 rating), felt as though he/she is part of the intellectual effort and not just a technical assistant (4.5 rating), and learned more about professional organizations and networking in engineering, and/or the sciences (4.1 rating). All students indicated that they would recommend the program to their friends.

Another measure of the UnCoRe impact on the REU student participants is the type of feedback we hear from the students after they have left the program. For example, a female student sent us an email stating "I'm delighted to tell you that I was accepted to 3 wonderful programs: The Princeton MS in CS (with thesis), the Duke Masters of Science in Economics and Computation (MSEC), and University of Michigan MS in CSE. Even more, the Princeton and Duke programs with a full tuition waiver!" The students' feedbacks like this received several years later are our ultimate reward and indicator of the impact of the UnCoRe REU program.
